moves.7... O-O 8. Nd2: In order to support the other knight.
moves.10. Ndf3: Black played very well the opening. My plan, advance g4, castling queenside, and Bd3. Pretty boring.
moves.10... Ne4: Now f6 comes. How to react? Either supporting the bishop (g3?!) or threatening something else.
moves.11. Bb5 f6 12. Nxc6: Losing a piece, with BxB. But black blunders it.
moves.14... Ng5 15. O-O: The knight exchange allows him to push e5, but allows me two developement moves. I'll take them.
moves.19... exf3 e.p. 20. Rxf3: A move for developement. No use in pushing the bishop in f3.
moves.20... f4: Ok, unavoidable, but maybe an overextension.
moves.21... g6 22. Qh6: This sets and advantage: g6 is pinned to the black queen. Incredibly, this makes me win the game.
moves.25... fxg3 e.p. 26. Rf3xf5 Rxf5 27. Rxf5: Black loses a rook, and the pawn in g3 is not enough to balance.

opening: Queen's pawn, Mason variation, Steinitz counter-gambit (D00)
